sub.page.title: Preview: Rules for Computing with Determinants

block.para: The following rules for computing with determinants lead to an interpretation of determinants as `oriented volume' and, in addition, can often simplify the process of evaluating a determinant
Multilinear When applying the determinant operation to (n,n)-matrices, varying one column vector, while keeping the others fixed, yields a linear function \RNr[n] \to \RNr. For example:

math.display.latex: \aligned \det \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & {\color{red} 3} + {\color{green} a} & 7 \\ 1 & {\color{red} 6} + {\color{green} b} & 2 \\ 1 & {\color{red} 9} + {\color{green} c} & 1 \end{array} \right]\ &=\ \det \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & {\color{red} 3} & 7 \\ 1 & {\color{red} 6} & 2 \\ 1 & {\color{red} 9} & 1 \end{array} \right]\ +\ \det \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & {\color{green} a} & 7 \\ 1 & {\color{green} b} & 2 \\ 1 & {\color{green} c} & 1 \end{array} \right] \\ &=\ {\color{red} 3}\cdot \det \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & {\color{red} 1} & 7 \\ 1 & {\color{red} 2} & 2 \\ 1 & {\color{red} 3} & 1 \end{array} \right]\ +\ \det \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & {\color{green} a} & 7 \\ 1 & {\color{green} b} & 2 \\ 1 & {\color{green} c} & 1 \end{array} \right] \endaligned
